div.div:
Identifying graphs where some problem exists across graphs like graphs having different scales, so that it can be identified when some set of variables are 'equivalent alternates' that preserve the 'problem differences' so that checking whether one scale has a related network like a 'causal variable network' that is more complete is a way to identify which scale the problem should be solved on.
The variables (or interfaces) need to be connected in some way like where 'one variable is an item in a set contained by the other interface' or where the 'variables are in a causal sequence'.
The point of this is to identify when solving one of the problems is necessary rather than solving all of the problems (like solving the problem on one interface in the causal sequence is all that's required).
Identifying all the similarities that preserve 'usefulness of a solution' across interface variables like 'scale' is a related intent.
Identifying the 'network of these similarities that preserve usefulness of a solution' is another related intent, so that 'one solution can be applied across that network of similarities' and identifying 'useful generalizations/specifications of that network' to 'identify more useful variants like more specific interface variable connections that preserve solution usefulness' is another related intent.
